rev.diff:
Line 2: Line 2:
'''William Dudley Haywood''' ([[February 4]], [[1869]]–[[May 18]], [[1928]]), better known as '''Big Bill Haywood''', was a prominent figure in the [[Labor unions in the United States|American labor movement]]. Haywood was a leader of the [[Western Federation of Miners]] (WFM), a founding member and leader of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW), and a member of the Executive Committee of the [[Socialist Party of America]]. During the first two decades of the 20th century, he was involved in several important labor battles, including the Colorado Labor Wars, the [[Lawrence textile strike]], and other textile strikes in [[Massachusetts]] and [[New Jersey]].
'''William Dudley Haywood''' ([[February 4]], [[1869]]–[[May 18]], [[1928]]), better known as '''Big Bill Haywood''', was a prominent figure in the [[Labor unions in the United States|American labor movement]]. Haywood was a leader of the [[Western Federation of Miners]] (WFM), a founding member and leader of the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] (IWW), and a member of the Executive Committee of the [[Socialist Party of America]]. During the first two decades of the 20th century, he was involved in several important labor battles, including the Colorado Labor Wars, the [[Lawrence textile strike]], and other textile strikes in [[Massachusetts]] and [[New Jersey]].
â
Never one to shy from violent conflicts<ref name=dolgoff>Dolgoff.</ref>, Haywood was frequently the target of prosecutors. His trial for the murder of [[Frank Steunenberg]] in 1907 (of which he was acquitted) drew national attention; in 1918, he was one of 101 IWW members convicted of violating the [[Espionage Act of 1917]]. While out of prison during an appeal of his conviction, Haywood fled to [[Russia]]<!--NOTE: didn't become Soviet Union until 1922; Haywood went there in 1921, when it was still Russia -->, where he would spend the remaining years of his life.
+
Haywood was an advocate of [[industrial unionism]],<ref name=pbs>PBS Interactive.</ref> a labor philosophy that favors organizing all workers in an industry under one union, regardless of the specific trade or skill level; this was in contrast to the [[craft union|craft unions]] that were prevailant at the time, such as the [[AFL]].<Ref name=cahn-137-169>Cahn, 137,169.</Ref> His belief that workers of all enthnicities should be united also clashed with many unions.<ref name=zinn-337-339>Zinn, 337-339.</ref> His strong preference for [[direct action]] over political tactics alienated him from the Socialist Party, and contributed to his dismissal in 1913.<ref name=dolgoff>Dolgoff.</ref>
  +   +
Never one to shy from violent conflicts<ref name=dolgoff />, Haywood was frequently the target of prosecutors. His trial for the murder of [[Frank Steunenberg]] in 1907 (of which he was acquitted) drew national attention; in 1918, he was one of 101 IWW members convicted of violating the [[Espionage Act of 1917]]. While out of prison during an appeal of his conviction, Haywood fled to [[Russia]]<!--NOTE: didn't become Soviet Union until 1922; Haywood went there in 1921, when it was still Russia -->, where he spent the remaining years of his life.
==Biography==
==Biography==
===Early life===
===Early life===
â
Haywood was born in 1869 in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. His father, a [[Pony Express]] rider, died of pneumonia when Haywood was three years old.<ref name=linder>Linder.</ref> At age nine, he injured his right eye while [[whittling]], permanently blinding it. Haywood never had his damaged eye replaced with a [[glass eye]]; when photographed, he would turn his head to show his left profile. Also at age nine, he began working in the [[Mining|mines]]; he never received much formal education. After brief stints as a [[cowboy]] and a [[homesteader]], he returned to mining in 1896.<ref name=pbs>PBS Interactive.</ref> High-profile events such as the destruction of the [[Molly Maguires]],<ref name=haywood>Haywood, 59.</ref> the [[Haymarket Riot]] in 1886 and the [[Pullman Strike]] in 1894 fostered Haywood's interest in the labor movement.<ref name=linder />
+
Haywood was born in 1869 in [[Salt Lake City, Utah]]. His father, a [[Pony Express]] rider, died of pneumonia when Haywood was three years old.<ref name=linder>Linder.</ref> At age nine, he injured his right eye while [[whittling]], permanently blinding it. Haywood never had his damaged eye replaced with a [[glass eye]]; when photographed, he would turn his head to show his left profile. Also at age nine, he began working in the [[Mining|mines]]; he never received much formal education. After brief stints as a [[cowboy]] and a [[homesteader]], he returned to mining in 1896.<ref name=pbs /> High-profile events such as the destruction of the [[Molly Maguires]],<ref name=haywood>Haywood, 59.</ref> the [[Haymarket Riot]] in 1886 and the [[Pullman Strike]] in 1894 fostered Haywood's interest in the labor movement.<ref name=linder />
===Western Federation of Miners involvement===
===Western Federation of Miners involvement===
Line 67: Line 67:
</blockquote>
</blockquote>
â
Gompers was an advocate of [[Craft unionism|craft unionism]],<Ref>Cahn, 137,169.</Ref> the idea that workers should be separated into unions according to their skills. The AFL disdained to organize workers who were not skilled.<Ref name=carlson-80>Carlson, 80.</Ref> Furthermore, in 1900 Gompers became the first vice-president of the [[National Civic Federation]], which was "dedicated to the fostering of harmony and collaboration between capital and organized labor."<Ref>Cahn, 204.</Ref> But Haywood had become convinced by the experiences of striking railroad workers that a different union philosophy, some form of [[Industrial unionism|industrial unionism]], was necessary for workers to obtain justice. This first became apparent in 1888 when the craft-organized locomotive firemen kept their engines running, helping their employers to break a strike called by the railroad engineers.<Ref name=carlson-44>Carlson, 44.</Ref>
+
Gompers was an advocate of [[Craft unionism|craft unionism]],<Ref name=cahn-137-169 /> the idea that workers should be separated into unions according to their skills. The AFL disdained to organize workers who were not skilled.<Ref name=carlson-80>Carlson, 80.</Ref> Furthermore, in 1900 Gompers became the first vice-president of the [[National Civic Federation]], which was "dedicated to the fostering of harmony and collaboration between capital and organized labor."<Ref>Cahn, 204.</Ref> But Haywood had become convinced by the experiences of striking railroad workers that a different union philosophy, some form of [[Industrial unionism|industrial unionism]], was necessary for workers to obtain justice. This first became apparent in 1888 when the craft-organized locomotive firemen kept their engines running, helping their employers to break a strike called by the railroad engineers.<Ref name=carlson-44>Carlson, 44.</Ref>
[[Eugene V. Debs]] had been head of the locomotive firemen's union, but he resigned to create the [[American Railway Union]] (ARU), organized industrially to include all railroad workers.<Ref>Carlson, 45.</Ref> In June of 1894, the ARU voted to join in solidarity with the ongoing [[Pullman Strike|Pullman strike]]. Railroad traffic throughout the nation was "largely paralyzed. The effectiveness of the industrial form of unionism was evident from the start."<Ref>Cahn, 174.</Ref> Although the strike was eventually crushed by government intervention and the failure of AFL officials to support Deb's call for a general strike in response,<Ref>Cahn, 176.</Ref> the power of workers crossing their trade lines and jurisdictional boundaries to join together in a fight against capital greatly impressed Haywood. He described the revelation of such power as "a great rift of light."<Ref name=carlson-44 />
[[Eugene V. Debs]] had been head of the locomotive firemen's union, but he resigned to create the [[American Railway Union]] (ARU), organized industrially to include all railroad workers.<Ref>Carlson, 45.</Ref> In June of 1894, the ARU voted to join in solidarity with the ongoing [[Pullman Strike|Pullman strike]]. Railroad traffic throughout the nation was "largely paralyzed. The effectiveness of the industrial form of unionism was evident from the start."<Ref>Cahn, 174.</Ref> Although the strike was eventually crushed by government intervention and the failure of AFL officials to support Deb's call for a general strike in response,<Ref>Cahn, 176.</Ref> the power of workers crossing their trade lines and jurisdictional boundaries to join together in a fight against capital greatly impressed Haywood. He described the revelation of such power as "a great rift of light."<Ref name=carlson-44 />
Line 117: Line 117:
Unlike many labor leaders and organizations of the time, Haywood believed that workers of all ethnicities should organize into the same union. According to Haywood, the IWW was "big enough to take in the black man, the white man; big enough to take in all nationalities - an organization that will be strong enough to obliterate state boundaries; to obliterate national boundaries."<ref name=orth>Orth.</ref>
Unlike many labor leaders and organizations of the time, Haywood believed that workers of all ethnicities should organize into the same union. According to Haywood, the IWW was "big enough to take in the black man, the white man; big enough to take in all nationalities - an organization that will be strong enough to obliterate state boundaries; to obliterate national boundaries."<ref name=orth>Orth.</ref>
â
In 1912, Haywood spoke at a convention for the [[Brotherhood of Timber Workers]] in [[Louisiana]]; at the time, interracial meetings in the state were illegal.<ref name=zinn-337-339>Zinn, 337-339.</ref> Haywood insisted that the white workers invite the [[African American]] workers to their convention, declaring:
+
In 1912, Haywood spoke at a convention for the [[Brotherhood of Timber Workers]] in [[Louisiana]]; at the time, interracial meetings in the state were illegal.<ref name=zinn-337-339 /> Haywood insisted that the white workers invite the [[African American]] workers to their convention, declaring:
<blockquote>You work in the same mills together. Sometimes a black man and a white man chop down the same tree together. You are meeting in a convention now to discuss the conditions under which you labor. Why not be sensible about this and call the Negroes into the Convention? If it is against the law, this is one time when the law should be broken.<ref name=zinn-337-339/></blockquote>
<blockquote>You work in the same mills together. Sometimes a black man and a white man chop down the same tree together. You are meeting in a convention now to discuss the conditions under which you labor. Why not be sensible about this and call the Negroes into the Convention? If it is against the law, this is one time when the law should be broken.<ref name=zinn-337-339/></blockquote>
